How can the joint probability be rewritten using conditional probability?

P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B): It measures how likely an event A is, given that event B has happened.

State the law of total probability.
P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B): If {Aᵢ} forms a partition of Ω, then P(B) = ΣᵢP(B|Aᵢ)P(Aᵢ)

What does it mean for two events to be independent?
P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B): P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) or, equivalently, P(A|B) = P(A)

What does it mean for two events to be conditionally independent given a third event?
P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B): P(A ∩ B | C) = P(A | C)P(B | C)

State Bayes' rule for the discrete case.
P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B): p(X = k | E) = [p(E | X = k)p(X = k)] / [Σₖ'p(E | X = k')p(X = k')]
